title: 104_s1623
content:
The "Travel and Tourism Partnership Act of 1996" establishes the National Tourism Board. The National Tourism Board is established with 36 members appointed by the President, including a Chairperson, members nominated by the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate, and employees from Federal and State travel agencies. The National Tourism Board consists of 36 members appointed by the President, including a Chairperson, members from Federal and State travel agencies, and representatives from the private sector. The Chairperson is accountable to the President and Congress for the Board's operations. Members serve 3-year terms, with initial members appointed for staggered terms of 1 to 2 years. The National Tourism Board consists of 36 members appointed by the President, including a Chairperson. Members serve staggered 2 to 3-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and meet at least semiannually. Despite its functions, the Board is not considered a Federal agency. The National Tourism Board, despite its functions, is not considered a Federal agency and is exempt from certain federal laws governing the operation of Federal agencies. This includes civil service laws, the Federal Advisory Committee Act, and other provisions related to personnel or budgetary matters. SEC. 102. DUTIES OF THE BOARD. The Board is responsible for facilitating public-private partnerships for travel and tourism policymaking, developing a national strategy to increase tourism in the United States, advising the President and Congress on implementation of the strategy, providing guidance to the National Tourism Organization, and developing recommendations on relevant issues. The Board may present testimony to Congress and State legislatures on relevant issues and submit reports to the President and Congress regarding its findings and determinations. The Board has powers to obtain information from Federal agencies and accept gifts or donations. It is prohibited from accepting Federal financial assistance. Additionally, the Board has personnel matters to attend to. The Board members serve without compensation, except for travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel to assist the Board in its duties. The Chairperson of the Board may appoint an executive director and personnel as needed. The Chairperson can determine their compensation. The National Tourism Organization may provide support services to the National Tourism Board upon request. Establishment of National Tourism Organization under Title II with Section 201. The President shall establish a nonprofit corporation called the National Tourism Organization to increase the US market share in global tourism and implement promotional programs overseas. The National Tourism Organization aims to partner with the travel industry, establish a data bank for market research, and promote US travel at international trade shows. The Organization Board, consisting of 45 members appointed by the President, will oversee its operations. The Organization Board, consisting of 45 members appointed by the President, will serve as incorporators and establish the Organization as a corporation under applicable law. The term of office for each member appointed by the President is 3 years, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board will be headed by a chairperson selected from among its members. The Organization Board, with 45 members appointed by the President, will establish the Organization as a corporation. Members are not considered US officers or employees. The Organization will have a president and other officers appointed by the Board, who will also hire staff. Officers serve at the pleasure of the Board. The Organization Board will hire staff and set their compensation. They will also work on developing a long-term financing recommendation within a year of the Organization's incorporation. SEC. 202. COOPERATION BY THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.

(a) Technical Assistance.--Federal agencies must provide technical assistance to the Organization upon request to help achieve its purposes.
(b) Overseas Posts.--Federal agencies with offices in foreign countries should incorporate programs that align with the recommendations of the National Tourism Board and the Organization.

SEC. 203. TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to reflect recommendations from the National Tourism Board established under the Travel and Tourism Partnership Act of 1996. This includes changes in subsection (c) and (d)(1) of the Act. The president of the National Tourism Organization established under the Travel and Tourism Partnership Act of 1996.
